content: How can Congress pass a law that allows for industry bonuses in one month (the Stimulus Package in February) and in the next month, in a reflection of public outrage over the (legal) AIG bonuses, pass another bill that taxes those bonuses at the 90% level? The verbal gymnastics that the House Democrats are doing to explain this are amazing. Half of the House Republicans went along with the herd stampede. This bill an ex postal facto tax and blatantly confiscatory and therefore illegal on both counts. It hits a lot of people who did absolutely nothing wrong. In the case of AIG, the people who caused the meltdown of the Financial Products division are long gone and the ones who are left are working to clean up the mess on behalf of the taxpayer, since we own most of the company now. Many of the AIG people are going to return their bonuses and a letter of resignation in protest to this Bill, leaving the taxpayer on the hook for much of our bailout money, because no one else has the expertise historical knowledge needed to unwind the remaining hundreds of billions of bad deals (they have already fixed hundreds of billions). Rather than exercise some mature, adult leadership and say this bill is not only hypocritical, illegal and probably counterproductive, the Speaker and the rest of the Democratic leadership allowed to come to a vote, just because the people are angry at something they don't really understand. And Obama is talking about signing it if gets through the Senate. This is absurd! *http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/03/19/bonus.bill/index.html*

content: I don't agree with bailouts on principle, be they Bush's bailouts or Obama's. If I mismanage a small buiness that I created and it fails, the government doesn't help me. It's pretty unfair when corporations, who have all the resources and talent in the world knowingly make bad decisions and then get paid. I'm against deregulation for the same reason. It allows the problems to continue and get worse. The economy is a fluid, flexible, complicated thing and using a set doctrine (socialism, unconstrained capitalism) in the face of reality is foolish. We need to balance taxes, regulation, funding, and the free market in order to make things work. Bailouts will not work in the long run because they reinforce bad behavior. Executives who run their companies into the ground need be kicked out on the street to live with their workers.
